title: family sell everything start new
story: NewsFamily sell everything they own to start new le travelling world in caravanThe Rogers family went to Alaska, Canada, New Zealand, Vanuatu, Switzerland, Italy, Germany, Austria, Hong Kong and Australia,ShareCommentsByBrendan McFaddenScott Thompson:,  JUN NewsThe Rogers family at Times Square, New York in the US "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailMeet the family of four who turned their back on the rat race and travelled the world in a caravan.Book seller, Joanna Rogers,  and her electrician husband, Oliver,  from Moriac, Australia , have always believed travel is an important part of family le. In  they took their two children Jameson, , and Evelyn, , out of public school , sold all their possessions and bought the caravan.Between  and  the family toured Alaska, Canada, New Zealand, Vanuatu, Switzerland, Italy, Germany, Austria, Hong Kong and Australia.  Joanna and Oliver decided in  that leaving their children at school for six hours a day, five days a week was far too long and they no longer wanted to live within societies guidelines and decided to travel together.The family sold their home they had owned since January . Oliver sold his business as an electrician, they bought a WD and a caravan and in January  they set off on an amazing journey around the world. Since then they have travelled along the East coast of Australia and since March, theyaposve been road-tripping across America and Canada.    Despite money being a problem and their kids missing their friends they have no intention of ever stopping. In January  my husband and I decided that work five or six days a week to pay a mortgage and sending our kids away from us for education was not sitting well with us, Joanna said. We only get a few short years with our kids and it felt like the time was slipping through our fingers. So, we decided to apostime outapos from the le society had dictated to us.  We always put aside time to travel, over the past five years we have been to, Alaska, Canada, New Zealand, Vanuatu, Europe, Hong Kong and travelled dferent parts of Australia.So, we sold our family home and Oliver gave up his business as an electrician which weaposd spent eight years building. We pulled our kids out of school, bought a WD and a caravan and set off on the adventure of a letime. Since we set off full time in January we have travelled along the east coast of Australia from Melbourne to Brisbane. Then since March we have been road-tripping across America and Canada.  Our absolute highlights have been New York City, Alberta in Canada and without a doubt our slow travel down the Pacic North West Coast.Of course the real highlights are very simple - spending every day with each other, no getting up early for work, no prepping for school, no after school activities or weekend madness. Joanna has had to adapt to being a teacher as well as a mother, which has been challenging at times. Both children are enrolled at an online school in Australia where they have regular contact with their own teachers. Although the two siblings get along very well, they sometimes miss their friends, but they have also made lots of new ones on the road.  Throughout their travels the family have seen their savings dip without a pay cheque which has taken some adjusting to. In November they willto their hometown where Joanna will work the peak period in the local book shop and Oliver will find the odd electricianaposs jobs.They plan to do this every year, so they can continue to travel for  months a year. Itaposs been hard getting the mindset of being aposteacherapos to our kids. Both are enrolled into an online school in Australia that are designed for long distance learners. Our children have classes three mornings a week. They have their own teachers who mark their own work and write reports on their progress, Joanna said.  Jameson and Evelyn get along very well, and we love being around them. Typically, they miss their friends especially Jameson, but they manage to make friends wherever they go. Australia is full of travelling families, so I know theyaposll be ok. Watching the savings account go down with no money coming in has taken some adjusting to. Because we want to continue travelling, we have decided to work two months a year. So in November Iaposll go back to work at the local book store in our hometown and Oliver will find electrician work. Itaposs incredibly cheap to travel in this way and we can easily get by on per week. We often get to camp freely and enjoy free activities like hiking and surfing. Itaposs very easy to not spend money.To be honest we canapost see ourselves ever ing to a typical lestyle again. We canapost wait for our big Australian lap tour over two years and then we want to go back to Europe. Some of our family come from the generation where work and money are the number one priority and understandably, they had their concerns. Over time though theyaposve seen how the le we are giving our kids is absolutely priceless.On a final note itaposs important to take hold of your le. You donapost have to own a house and you do not need to have a fancy car. Money doesnapost equal happiness. Our children are with us for such a short time in this le. Go out and live your best le possible with them.

How many children does Boris Johnson have  An audibly floundering Mr Mercer replied: Iaposm really not interested in Boris Johnsonaposs family le. Ms Barnett pressed on, explaining in detail about why she thought the question was important. The radio host said: Because right nowyou google aposBoris Johnson, how many children does he haveapos - and Iaposll explain why I am asking this - it comes up as four. That is with his still we, but now separated, Marina Wheeler. But there was a court case in  where a woman lost a privacy case. The Judge said it was in the public interest while he was in office that he had an extramarital affair with a woman who later gave birth to a daughter while he was married. It then came out in that court case that it was alleged he had another child out of wedlock. So it is between five and six children that our future Prime Minister has. Would you not say it is fair and right to get an answer to the question of how many children our next Prime Minister has  Mr Mercer replied: Discussing our private lives is a decision that public figures like me make.    I have chosen to discuss mine, Boris has not chosen not to discuss his and he is well within his rights to do that. Ms Barnett asked again - saying: The Master of the Rolls, in that case, said it was a apospublic interest matter which the electorate was entitled to know when considering his fitness for high public office. This is not my Mary Whitehouse moment, this is me asking you then a dferent question - why do you think he has chosen not to be honest about something as basic as how many children he has  Mr Mercer replied: What Boris chooses to do in his personal le and what he chooses to talk about is entirely a matter for him. It would be entirely inappropriate for me to talk about any of that. Boris Johnson is currently orcing his we Marina Wheeler.    The couple, who married in , have four children together - Lara, Milo Arthur, Cassia Peaches, and Theodore Apollo. The case mentioned by Ms Barnett revolved around his fth child with art consultant Helen Macintyre. The court decided that Mr Johnsonaposs identity as the father of her daughter Stephanie could be made public. Ms Barnett referenced a potential sixth child mentioned in court documents. No sixth child of Mr Johnson has ever been publicly acknowledged. The references in the judgement, which states this is the second time that he hascaused a woman who was not his we to become pregnant, may refer to the pregnancy terminated by another former lover of the Mr Johnson, Petronella Wyatt. Mr Johnsonaposs spokesperson declined to comment.

title: labour mp says shes being
story: NewsLabour MP says shes being forced choose between being a mum and being an MPStella Creasy is expecting her first child but is worried about how to juggle her role with being a mumShareByNicola BartlettPolitical Correspondent:,  JUN NewsStella Creasy is expecting her first child "Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA Labour MP has said she feels parliamentaposs rules mean she is being told to “choose between being a mum and being an MP”.  Stella Creasy said the parliamentary standards authority has told her pregnant women it does not recognise any form of maternity leave. The MP for Walthamstow in London, who is expecting her first child, had asked for extra funding for staff and more support. She decided to speak out after experiencing two miscarriages during which she was forced to continue to work as normal. “Heartbroken by all the years that I have struggled with fertility, I’ve kept these events to myself and made sure my constituents have never been affected,” she writes.“Now I’m pregnant once more and terried – not just that it will go wrong again, but because I know that my resolve to keep my private and professional lives separate has become impossible.” Writing in thethe campaigning MP explained how during her first miscarriage she was forced to keep working while “aching and bleeding”, including joining a protest for the extradition of a man who had raped and murdered a constituent. After her second miscarriage she said she had to arrange the medical procedure around constituency advice surgeries. Ms Creasy says the way that the parliamentary authorities deal with pregnancy is not fair. “Humiliatingly, it is making me beg for extra staff funding – or give up any chance of spending time with my child to make sure my constituents don’t miss out,” she writes. “If a GP or vicar were on leave, a locum would be provided to ensure continuity of services. In Denmark, a member of the national parliament would have a substitute MP appointed.” Earlier this year proxy voting was introduced for MPs after fellow Labour MP Tulip Siddiq was forced to delay her cesarean and travel through the voting lobbies in a wheelchair to have her say on a key Brexit vote.Ms Siddiq, who gave birth to her second child this year, said she didnapost even ask the authorities for extra help because she had such a negative reaction first time around. She explained to the : I was told ‘we have not got a historic policy on that because we have not had many women in parliament who give birth’,” she said. The Hampstead and Kilburn MP said that proxy voting had make things much easier but that in many ways it was hard for others to step in and cover the job of an MP. She said she responded to emails from hospital but was helped by neighbouring MP Keir Starmer when it came to attending events. “He helped because we unofficially paired up, but that was the goodness of his heart. If you share a borough with an opposition MP, they wouldn’t do it,” she said.

title: tory leadership 13 things learned
story: NewsTory leadership:  things we learned as candidates faced journalists hustingsFrom TV licences to Universal Credit, weve grilled the Tory leadership hopefuls - except chicken Boris Johnson of course. Heres what we found outShareCommentsByDan BloomOnline Political EditorNicola BartlettPolitical CorrespondentMikey Smith:,  JUN Updated:,  JUN Newsthis.style.displaynone"Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news politics video tory-leadership-race-six-candidates-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news politics  , theme : # , title : Mirror Politics , options :,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,mvtTests.enable:true,swipeNavigation:true,irisClientToken:,externalBrandCSS:true,irisTvEnabled:true,imaVersion:,displayPrebidEnabled:true,modularCss:true,nativeAppBanner:true,amazonVideoTagEnabled:true,amazonTagEnabled:true,mvtTests:,videoPrebidEnabled:true,video.suppressDates:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news politics  , theme : # , title : Mirror Politics , options :,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,mvtTests.enable:true,swipeNavigation:true,irisClientToken:,externalBrandCSS:true,irisTvEnabled:true,imaVersion:,displayPrebidEnabled:true,modularCss:true,nativeAppBanner:true,amazonVideoTagEnabled:true,amazonTagEnabled:true,mvtTests:,videoPrebidEnabled:true,video.suppressDates:true""Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email Tory leader hopefuls have fielded two hours of questions on Brexit , Universal Credit , Trump - and much more. All of them, that is, except chicken Boris Johnson.Once again the blonde-haired Brexiteer blushed his way out of hard questions from Westminster journalists. It was a full on-the-record debate, and it only didnapost appear on TV because Parliamentary authorities said no. Yet shy and retiring Mr Johnson will only face a BBC TV debate tomorrow night, after at least one of his rivals has been knocked out of the contest. Even without the  -odds frontrunner, however, we did learn some valuable things from todayaposs lobby hustings. From their views on Universal Credit to whether or not they were in MI, here are  things we learned. Boris Johnson did not attend the hustings because - weaposre told - he had to prepare for tomorrowaposs debate.It was the second event heaposd shamelessly boycotted in two days, having been empty-podiumed by Channel  last night.Michael Gove sniped: Someone put it to me that these hustings without Boris was like Hamlet without the prince.Of course we all remember that at the end of Hamlet he isnapost the king. Now Iaposm not suggesting that that means we should go for a Norway option. But I do think itaposs the case that it ainapost over until itaposs over.But Jeremy Hunt, who could soon be asking for a job in a Johnson government, was less keen to slag him off.He shrugged everyone makes mistakes when asked about Boris Johnsonaposs comments about Nazanin Zaghari-Ratclfe. The then-Foreign Secretary is accused of ening the British mumaposs jail term in Iran after he incorrectly told MPs she had been training journalists. Yet Mr Hunt said: Everyone makes mistakes as Foreign Secretary. You are constantly making very finely balanced judgements and it is possible to get things wrong and Iaposm sure Iaposll get things wrong in the future as well. . Jeremy Hunt BACKED Trumpaposs attack on Londonaposs mayor   Jeremy Hunt BACKED Donald Trump over a series of attacks on Sadiq Khan - despite them being branded racist.The Foreign Secretary said he agreed % with the sentiment behind the US Presidentaposs attack on Londonaposs mayor - despite the attack including the word Londonistan. Asked directly about the word aposLondonistanapos, Mr Hunt admitted I wouldn’t use those words myself but did not explicitly condemn the phrase. He added: The sentiment is enormous disappointment that we have a Mayor of London who has completely failed to tackle kne crime and spent more time on politics than the actual business of making Londoners safer. “And in that, I % agree with the President.”His comment comes despite three of his Tory rivals, Sajid Javid, Michael Gove and Dominic Raab, all slamming the President.  Rory Stewart added I feel very strongly that you should be firm with world leaders, but that discussions of this kind should happen privately.. Meanwhile, the next PM offers little hope for Northern Ireland abortion campaigners...  A major issue has been whether the UK government steps in and legalises abortion in Northern Ireland.Dominic Raab said he believes passionately in a woman’s right to choose, wants to avoid unwanted pregnancies.But he said he would not extend abortion rights to Northern Ireland, because he doesn’t want to risk destroying the constitutional framework of the UK.Jeremy Hunt did not commit to changing the law either.He has previously repeated his long-held beliefs that the time limit should be reduced from  to  weeks but said that he had no plans to change the law as it stands. On Northern Ireland he said only that he had provided funding for women in Northern Ireland to access abortions as health secretary. The other candidates were not asked but have so far given no indication. ... Or Universal Credit claimants  None of the candidates who were asked committed to a major overhaul of Universal Credit.Jeremy Hunt refused to saythe rollout of Universal Credit has pushed people to food banks - and signalled he wouldnapost halt the rollout.He told the Mirror Universal Credit is the right way forward adding: Youaposve always got to be compassionate and humane when you look at the way these reforms are being rolled out. Iaposd always be willing to look at that, to review the way Universal Credit is being rolled out to make sure we do it in the fairest possible way. But the principle is right.Sajid Javid suggested he wouldnapost change the five-week wait for first payment - saying he wouldnapost make fundamental changes, despite wanting more fairness and dignity.He added registering should be faster and the appeals process overhauled.Michael Gove also refused to say he would shorten the five-week wait for first payment. Askedhe would, he said: I donapost think radical changes but there are changes that need to be made.I think Amber Rudd has done a fantastic job of at Work and Pensions in order to deal with some of the teething problems with Universal Credit. There are some specic problems that relate to the interaction between Universal Credit and income tax which mean that for the working poor we may need to do more and Iaposm eager to do that.Dominic Raab did not commit to shortening the five-week wait either. He said: We need to make sure welfare is a safety net, but also a route out of the welfare trap.Need to make sure we can amend the system and revise the system so it is as sensitive as it needs to be for those who are struggling. . But thereaposs some hope for free TV licences Jeremy Hunt became the second surviving leadership hopeful to pledge a U-turn - and keep free TV licences for over-s.It comes after the BBC announced it would restrict the benefit to only the poorest OAPs on Pension Credit. The decision is set to take away .million householdsapos free TV licence from summer next year. Campaigners say the Tories should never have foisted the decision onto the BBC. The benefit was once managed by the state - and in  the Tories pledged to keep free licences for the over-s.Today, askedhe would honour that pledge, Mr Hunt told the Mirror: Yes. He joins Sajid Javid, whose spokeswoman said he would “commit to keeping” free TV licences.. There were some eye-popping attacks on Jeremy Corbyn   Jeremy Hunt said Jeremy Corbyn is against aspiration, he is against British values, he is against Britain. But itaposs Michael Gove who saved up the biggest attack. He said: I have fire in my belly. But more than that Jeremy Corbyn cannot [help] how he was born. He cannot help the accident of his birth. He cannot help that he was born into the purple of middle class.I would fight against Jeremy Corbyn and his Wykehamist educated allies to make sure that the poorest people in this country have a government that is on their side. The only way you can do that is by having someone like me, who is a warrior for the dispossessed, rather than someone like Jeremy Corbyn, who is, how can I put it …more comfortable making the case for Iran than he is for Britain’s working classes. . And furious mixed views on John Bercow In an appeal to MPs who accuse him of anti-Brexit bias, Jeremy Hunt launched a blistering attack on John Bercow.He said Mr Bercow would have “mixed record” and also be remembered as a “reforming” Speaker of the Commons. However, he added: “I profoundly disagree with the way he has used his office to further a particular political agenda. “I think the Speaker has to be impartial and that means recognising the government has a voice in Parliament, not just the opposition.”Yet Michael Gove defended the Speaker with an unusual excuse. He said: John and I have children at the same school so I wonapost speak ill of my good friend John Bercow.. They donapost like talking about their past acts Asked whether he had taken any drugs other than cocaine, Michael Gove replied: “I’ve answered all the questions about that when I was interviewed by Andrew Marr and also when I spoke to the Daily Mail. That was a full and complete statement.” Jeremy Hunt was asked whether he regretted likening the EU to the USSR in a speech at the Tory Party conference last year, saying: I think it showed Iaposm prepared to say things to friends they might not like and able to continue a relationship even saying those uncomfortable things. Dominic Raab was confronted with accusations that his version of events of meetings as Brexit Secretary was completely at odds with accounts from Brussels and the Irish government.To which he responded: Of course people in Brussels because in their own words I said to them things no one  dared to. . But they do all *claim* to have a plan for Brexit... All the candidates re-stated their plan for Brexit.Michael Gove - who wants to renegotiate the backstop and turbo-change tech arrangements for the Irish border - admitted it was a mistake to trigger Article  before having a plan for Brexit, and said he urged then-PM Theresa May to take a dferent course. Jeremy Hunt said he said he would go back to Brussels to try and renegotiate the existing Brexit deal. He claimedhe came with new ideas, a new PM, a fresh approach, the EU would be willing to be flexible. He didnapost rule out No Deal. Rory Stewart said heaposd try to pass Theresa Mayaposs three-times-defeated Brexit deal, approaching Labour MPs including Lisa Nandy. If that failed heaposd set up a aposCitizensapos Assemblyapos - with EU Brexit negotiator Barnier called to give evidence on the art of the possible. Dominic Raab insisted he would continue to pursue the Malthouse Compromise Brexit plan - for a renegotiated Northern Ireland backstop and a new transition period - and leave with No Dealneeded. Sajid Javid insisted Britain would still be the safest country in the world in a No Deal Brexit but said he would try to negotiate a better deal.... And it could involve summoning Michel Barnier to persuade Britain. And  Tory MPs voting against No Deal. Tory candidate Rory Stewart would work with Labour MPs and Michel Barnier to stop a hard Brexit, he declared. The leadership hopeful confirmed heaposd approach Labour MPs including Lisa Nandy in a bid to pass Theresa Mayaposs three-times-failed Brexit deal.If that failed heaposd set up a aposCitizensapos Assemblyapos on the way forward - with EU Brexit negotiator Barnier called to give evidence on the art of the possible.He also suggested up to  Tory MP colleagues would block No Deal Brexit through a vote without needing to bring down the government.. Rory Stewart is not a fuzzy Remainer lefty With his quirky manner and pronouncements against Brexit, you could be forgiven for thinking Rory Stewart is some kind of anti-Brexit left-wing zealot.But our questioning showed that image simply isnapost true. He refused to call an early general election, branding the idea catastrophic and dumb. The same went for a second referendum which he said would be isive,The Old Etonian has in fact slammed rivals for offering to spend too much on services like schools and police.And asked about his loyal Tory voting record, and whether he was being dishonest, he said: I’ve said from the very beginning I’m never going to spend any money I donapost have. I am a Conservative, I’m very proud of being a Conservative. I believe deeply in limited government, inidual rights, restraint abroad and prudence at home. . He also DENIES he worked for MI A former diplomat who walked across Afghanistan, Rory Stewart has previously admitted his career gives the impression he was a spy.He cemented that today, saying he doesnapost trust even his fellow Tory MPs in the voting lobbies. And to cap it all, askedhe had ever worked for MI, he replied with one word: No. Exactly what an MI agent WOULD say! . Despite everything, Michael Gove is looking forward to David Cameronaposs book Only yesterday Michael Gove admitted heaposd lost friends over his backing for Brexit. He was, of course, talking about David Cameron.But despite everything, Mr Gove said heaposs looking forward to former Prime Ministeraposs memoirs later this year. Askedhe fears the book he said: No, I’m looking forward to reading it. I think it will be brilliantly written. I think it’s been too long since we’ve heard from David in many ways. I think he was a great Prime Minister.

title: tory leadership hopefuls play down
story: NewsTory leadership hopefuls play down hope of radical changes to Universal CreditCandidates for Prime Minister said tweaks were needed to the six-in-one benefit - but none committed to a radical overhaulShareCommentsByDan BloomOnline Political Editor:,  JUN Updated:,  JUN NewsNone of the candidates committed to a major overhaul of Universal Credit "Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailTory leadership candidates have played down any hope they will push through radical reforms to Universal Credit. Four of the six current candidates for Prime Minister were today asked about the six-in-one benefit - after it drove people to food banks and destitution. Since the benefit began rolling out, it has had to have billions of pounds extra pumped into it amid furious complaints it left families without enough cash. The standard waiting time was cut from six weeks to five, advance loans were increased and better run-on payments introduced to stop people falling behind on rent. But charities and the Daily Mirror have urged Tory ministers to go further and pause the rollout. Questioned today, Tory leadership candidates accepted they could go further in reforming the benefit. None of the candidates who were asked today, however, committed to a total overhaul of Universal Credit.  Jeremy Hunt refused to sayhe believed the rollout of Universal Credit has pushed people to food banks - and signalled he wouldnapost halt it. He told the Mirror Universal Credit is the right way forward adding: Youaposve always got to be compassionate and humane when you look at the way these reforms are being rolled out. Iaposd always be willing to look at that, to review the way Universal Credit is being rolled out to make sure we do it in the fairest possible way. But the principle is right. Michael Gove also did not sayhe would shorten the five-week wait for first payment. He said: I donapost think radical changes but there are changes that need to be made. I think Amber Rudd has done a fantastic job of at Work and Pensions in order to deal with some of the teething problems with Universal Credit. There are some specic problems that relate to the interaction between Universal Credit and income tax which mean that for the working poor we may need to do more and Iaposm eager to do that.  Sajid Javid said: We can do more to bring more fairness and give a bit more dignity to the people that are using that system. It takes too long at the moment to register and then to get a response back from the system and just a few weeks would make a huge dference to someone. Also the appeals process needs to be overhauled, it should be more independent than it currently is. Dominic Raab did not commit to shortening the five-week wait but said welfare must be a safety net. He added: There are two things that are crucial - making sure that we amend the system or revise the system so itaposs as sensitive as it possibly can be to the changing and fluid needs of those who are struggling. Iaposd also want to incentivise the system so that weaposve got as much encouragement for people to go out and work and marginal rates of taxation are as low as possible.

story: NewsBooking apartment which cost £ for one night found in disgusting stateLiverpool fan David Anderson wanted to watch the Champions League final in the city and splashed out for the apartment at the Albert DockShareCommentsByChris Jaffray:,  JUN Updated:,  JUN NewsDavid Anderson and Nicky - David had wanted to stay in the city for the Champions League final "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA dad has revealed shocking images of a aposdisgustingapos apartment - where he says he found mouldy bread, doors with no handles and a sickening unknown yellow substance oozing across the floor. Liverpool fan David Anderson travelled to the city to watch his team compete in the Championaposs League final and paid £ for a one-night stay in the two-bedroom apartment at the Albert Dock River View Apartments. But the sales manager, , claims he was greeted with a dishwasher full of dirty and mouldy dishes, a toilet door with no handle and yellow goop he believes could be insect larvae on the floor of the building.David, who paid for the stay via Booking , claims he made numerous efforts to contact the propertyaposs owner but she allegedly blocked him - and was later told by the holiday site he was entitled to just £ compensation.   The dad-of-one, from Leicester, said: The whole place was disgusting. There was mouldy bread in the cupboard. I do no know what the bizarre yellow substance was, it seemed like insect eggs, I touched them and they were soft. The bedding looked like it was a fire hazard.    When I tried to speak to the owner to discuss the problems, she said aposyou should be lucky you got a room in Liverpool for £, and she has now blocked me on WhatsApp. It was so upsetting - the girls started crying but I said to everyone aposjust go and enjoy the dayapos. As soon as David saw his team had beaten Barcelona in the semi-finals he booked a hotel in Liverpool for his fiance and her daughter and his son and sonaposs girlfriend. But he claims he began to suspect something was wrong when he attempted to contact the owner about parking and when he would be let into the property and heard nothing back.  David alleges when he turned up at the apartment, no key had been left for him and he was told by the owner to reach into the letterbox and get it, but the gap was too small. He said it was only when he got inside the property he realised the full extent of the nightmare - discovering mouldy bread, cutlery covered in mould in the dishwasher, bedding in a cupboard which looked like a fire hazard and the unknown sickening yellow substance on the ground. On top of this, the toilet door had no handle meaning it could not be shut.    David said he tried to look where for alternative accommodation, but due to the fact around , people had descended on the city for the football found he would have been £, out of pocket to move somewhere , leaving he and his family no choice but to brave a stay. He said: I was fuming at the time. Booking said I should have rung and I would have got somewhere , but the reason I didnapost ring was because on their website there was nowhere available that wasnapost £ to £, for the night in Liverpool.When I rang booking I told them I wanted a full refund, they said on the basis of the pictures I should get £.We left on Sunday, thank God Liverpool won! A spokeswoman said: At Booking, our primary aim is to facilitate smooth and enjoyable trips for our customers, empowering them to make informed decisions about the types of travel experiences that are right for them.In the very rare instance that something unexpected occurs at a property, our customer service team are available   to support further, just as we have done in this case, negotiating on this customeraposs behalf and providing a full refund.

title: boy going school blue water
story: NewsBoy going to school with blue water loses sight as mum demands arsenic testsConcerns have been raised over blue drinking water at Buchanan High in Coatbridge, in North Lanarkshire, Scotland and a number of teachers have been diagnosed with cancer.ShareCommentsByBrendan McFaddenJudith Tonner:,  JUN Updated:,  JUN NewsTommi Morgan, , has been blind since October - after suddenly developing an ulcer on his right cornea "Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA mum is demanding a probe to establisharsenic ground contamination at her -year-old sonaposs school contributed to him losing his sight. Concerns have been raised over blue drinking water at Buchanan High in Coatbridge, in North Lanarkshire, Scotland and a number of teachers have been diagnosed with cancer. Josie Morgan’s -year-old son Tommi, who has autism, is a first-year pupil at the school and has been blind since October - after suddenly developing an ulcer on his right cornea which has robbed him of his vision. Josie said medical tests have showed Tommi has three times the normal levels of arsenic in his system and the poor youngster is angry and frustrated after losing his sight.    She is demanding to know more about the likelihood of ground contamination at the school, which is built on a former industrial site. She will be meeting NHS Lanarkshire officials next week and her case has been referenced at the Scottish Parliament by constituency MSP Alex Neil. Josie said: “Tommi’s vision was perfect before he started high school but he then took an ulcer which saw his eyesight deteriorate over the space of two weeks, and by early October he was totally blind. “We couldn’t work out what had happened and consultants were baffled as scans were coming back normal. “In February, I found out about what was happening with the water and made the doctors aware of it. Tommi was sent for new tests and it was found that his arsenic levels, which should be , were at .” She added: “I believe there’s a link. Arsenic doesn’t appear in a person’s system for no reason. We need to know where it has come from and to be able to pinpoint the source of this.    “I have a meeting with public health officials next week and have spoken to a lawyer, lots of councillors, and Alex Neil, who I can’t praise enough for his backing.” Josie told how a public meeting with officials from North Lanarkshire Council which is responsible for the school failed to shed any light on her concerns. She said: “The officials spoke most of the time and just repeated the same things. They’re adamant the school is safe but nobody got any answers and it didn’t fill us with any confidence. “I took the microphone and spoke about Tommi. I don’t know how I managed to do it but I told everybody what had happened to him and people were absolutely horried. “Now I want an independent inquiry, and everybody at the meeting was of the same opinion. We’re concerned about every child in the school and the fact that four teachers have cancer. It’s a flagship building and it’s a brilliant school – but there’s no use in it being brilliantit’s unsafe.” Josie says her son is a completely dferent wee laddie since losing his sight..  She said: “He had some tests three weeks ago and depending on how they come back, there’s a small chance he could be put on steroids and recover a little bit of vision, but they’re telling me it’s likely he’s not going to recover his sight. “Tommi is angry and frustrated. He’s been taken away from school, he can’t play games, there’s nothing he can do and his mental health has suffered as he’s missing his friends, school and routine, which is important with autism. “He’s known his school friends since they were in primary together – it took years to build relationships and he wouldn’t consider being sent to another school.” A spokesman for North Lanarkshire Council said: Specialist doctors from the public health department of NHS Lanarkshire have confirmed that there is no evidence to link attendance at the schools with an increased risk of cancer. They have also confirmed that no other serious illness is connected to attendance at the schools or the site on which they are built.“All the facts from all the lead organisations continue to confirm that the schools and the site on which they are built are safe.

title: dad 37 trapped forever foetal
story: NewsDad, , trapped forever in foetal position begs doctors to amputate his legWARNING - GRAPHIC IMAGE: Thomas McKell, from Glasgow, Scotland, has been fighting MRSA for four years and now has a gaping wound behind his knee thats untreatableShareCommentsByStephen StewartMatthew Dresch:,  JUN NewsThis shocking picture shows Thomas stuck in a hospital bed after a superbug left a gaping hole in his leg "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA dad begged doctors to amputate his leg after a flesh-eating bug gnawed its way through his leg, leaving him in agonising pain. Thomas McKell, from Glagsow, Scotland, made the desperate request because the MRSA bug that had eaten the skin and muscle behind his knee could not be treated.The former joiner, who has multiple sclerosis, is now unable to move his legs and is stuck in a foetal position in hospital, the Daily Record reports.Thomas, who has been fighting MRSA for the last four years, and his mum Pauline, , shared shocking pictures of him in hospital in a bid to get help for him. She said: “At one point, it was so bad, he said he wanted them to amputate his legs.”    “Thomas is severely disabled with MS and we just don’t know where to turn to. “We have been shoved from pillar to post and things just seem to get worse. He’s such a poor soul. “He was diagnosed with MS in his s. He used to be fit and active.He loved football and supported  Celtic  and even went to see them in Seville. He used to work as a joiner and was always on the go.“For four years, they have been cleaning the wound on his leg but it never seems to get any better. “It’s heartbreaking. We’re now told he has a category four MRSA wound. He is in a terrible state and even the plastic surgeon was shocked when he saw it. We just don’t know what to do for him.    “Surely someone shouldn’t just be left like this in this day and age ” Dad-of-two Thomas, , is stuck in the foetal position because of muscle wastage causing his legs to retract. He may have to have the tendons cut in his legs to allow them to be straightened. Health chiefs insist he is getting the right treatment and they promised to meet his family to discuss his care. But Pauline is appalled by his physical and mental state.    Thomas was treated in Glasgow Royal Infirmary but is now a patient in the city’s Queen Elizabeth University Hospital. Pauline, who also has MS, said they are still waiting for test results on his leg wound. Her comments on Thomas’s plight come after a Scottish hospital was investigated over the care of a multiple sclerosis patient stuck in the foetal position for more than two years. Former reservist soldier Billy Barclay, , was moved from Hairmyres Hospital in East Kilbride – where he had been trapped because a care home place couldn’t be found. His daughter Barbara said he received much better care at the Queen Elizabeth University Hospital. But staff there discovered he had two fractures and a serious infection. Social workers issued Hairmyres with an adult protection order over his care in .    “They are now talking about taking skin off his thighs to graft onto the wound. It is just one thing after another and everything seems to take so long to happen. Why does it have to be like that  “I am disgusted. The Duchess of Cambridge was all smiles as she chatted with Sophie, the Countess of Wessex, Queen Letizia of Spain, the Duchess of Cornwall and Queen Maxima of the Netherlands while attending the annual Order of the Garter Service. The -year-old looked elegant in a Catherine Walker aposLizaapos white coat dress featuring black lace and teamed it with a black Lock  Co hat and black clutch. The event, held at St Georgeaposs Chapel, was met with glorious sunshine while the streets were filled with hundreds of onlookers keen to catch a glimpse of the VIP visitors.  The afternoon began with pomp and pageantry as the band and the Household Cavalry marched the streets. Wearing the lavish velvet robes, glistening insignia and plumed hats of the Order of the Garter, the Queen and the royal knights processed through the grounds of Windsor Castle. The annual service, a -year-old tradition, is the oldest and most senior Order of Chivalry in Britain. Recipients of the honour of joining the order are chosen because they have held public office, contributed to national le or served the sovereign personally.  The appointment of Knights of the Garter is in the Queenaposs gt and is made without consulting ministers. King Felipe VI of Spain and King Willem-Alexander of the Netherlands were among those to receive a special honour and were installed as Supernumerary, or aposStrangerapos, Knights of the Garter. The pair proudly walked to St Georgeaposs Chapel with the Prince of Wales, Duke of Cambridge, Duke of York, Princess Royal and Earl of Wessex. They were watched by the Duchess of Cambridge, Duchess of Cornwall, Countess of Wessex and the two foreign Queens - the Spanish monarchaposs we Queen Letizia, and Queen Maxima, we of the Dutch king. The tradition honours those who have been knighted in recognition of their public service and was founded by Edward III in .  He was inspired by the tales of King Arthur and the chivalric Knights of the Round Table. The Knights, now both male and female, used to be limited to aristocracy, but today they are chosen from a iety of backgrounds, in recognition for their public service. Former Prime Minister Sir John Major, Lord Phillips of Worth Matravers, a past president of the Supreme Court, and Admiral Lord Boyce, a former head of the UKaposs armed forces are also Garter knights and were part of the procession in front of the royals. Their route was lined by troopers on foot from the Household Cavalryaposs Le Guards and Blues and Royals, wearing their plumed helmets and carrying swords.  The Queen, who arrived by state limousine, wore the grand traditional mantle and hat of the Order. The dark blue velvet mantle is embroidered with the Order of the Garter insignia and has a dark red sash attached to the right shoulder. It has been worn by members since the th century. She also wore a black velvet Tudor style bonnet, with a plume of white ostrich and heron feathers and the shield of St Georgeaposs cross. She teamed it with a Stewart Parvin gown in ivory, rose and gold.  Camilla, the Duchess of Cornwall, opted for a pale pink Anna Valentine dress coat and Philip Treacy hat, while Sophie, the Countess of Wessex, stunned in a white and coral Suzannah dress with Jane Taylor hat. Queen Maxima wore an outfit by Claes Iversen and a hat by Fabienne Delvigne. story: Gary Mackay-Steven#s Aberdeen exit could soon be confirmed, with reports saying he will join English League One side Portsmouth this week.Aberdeen had not given up hope of convincing Scotland international winger Mackay-Steven to remain at Pittodrie, but it is understood he will sign for Kenny Jackett#s Pompey.Mackay-Steven’s Dons deal expires on June  and it is understood New York City, who made an approach for the winger in January, have cooled their interest.However, the Dons’ hopes he would sign a new deal appear to have been dashed.Meanwhile, the Reds will find out tomorrow who they will play in the Europa League first qualying round.Aberdeen are seeded for the first and second rounds, with the first round draw at .pm tomorrow.Among the teams they could face are Liepaja of Latvia, Levadia Tallinn of Estonia, Wales’ Barry Town or Northern Ireland’s Cltonville, Saint Patrick’s of Ireland, RoPS Rovaniemi of Finland and Ki of the Faroe Islands or Tre Fiori of San Marino.

title: aberdeen airport workers set to take part in more strike action later this month
story: Workers at Aberdeen International Airport will go on strike again later this month.Members of the Unite union will walk out on June  and , between am and am, as the dispute with the airport’s owners AGS, over pay and the closing of their defined benefit pension scheme continues.Union chiefs say airport bosses had offered a “repackaged % pay offer” which it claims is materially the same as one tabled in April. Workers at the airport have already taken strike action this month.Shauna Wright, Unite regional industrial officer, said: “We want the public to understand that our members do not take this action lightly.“But, AGS have repeatedly set preconditions to any negotiations by stating they will not reopen the consultation on the pension scheme, which breaks our Acas agreement with them.”“For the record, Unite wants to reaffirm that we are always open to meaningful negotiations to seek a remedy to this dispute at any time, any place and under any auspices.”Steve Szalay, managing director of Aberdeen International Airport, said: “It’s extremely disappointing that the trade unions have served notice of further strike action, particularly when we have agreed a date for talks and tabled an improved offer with a view to reaching a resolution.“If they are serious about entering into meaningful dialogue then we would call on them to end the strike.“Despite the best efforts of the unions to cause disruption for the travelling public, we have kept our airport open ensuring thousands of passengers and hundreds of flights have been able to travel and operate safely.“We will once again put our contingency plans in place to ensure the unions do not cause disruption for passengers and airlines.”

title: crivvens oor wullies big bucket trail lands aberdeen
story: Dozens of le-sized sculptures of one of Scotland’s favourite comic characters have been installed around Aberdeen.Brightly-coloured statues of dungaree-clad scamp Oor Wullie have gone on display as part of Oor Wullie’s Big Bucket Trail, a nationwide art campaign in aid of children’s hospital charities. A total of  sculptures have been installed around Aberdeen, Dundee, Inverness, Edinburgh and Glasgow, while a further  miniature versions have been decorated by school pupils.Princess Beatrice of York, who is Patron of the Edinburgh Children’s Hospital Charity, will officially launch the trail.The purpose of the trail is to raise awareness for charities including the Archie Foundation, which works in partnership with the NHS to provide care to sick children in the north-east.The sculptures, each of which has been inidually designed by commissioned artists and sponsored by companies, will be auctioned off when the trail ends in September.David Wood, chief executive of Archie, said: “The Archie Foundation will ensure all funds raised from this event helps local sick children and their families.“Oor Wullie is a real mischievous character and I’m looking forward to seeing how each artist has interpreted him in their own way.“I hope the public will show support for Oor Wullie and Archie to help raise vital funds for children.” vw, px"  The trail is being held in conjunction with events company Wild in Art, as well as DC Thomson Media.Wild in Art director Charlie Langhorne said: “Wild in Art believes passionately in the power of creativity, enabling signicant funds to be raised for our charity partners as well as having major social and economic impacts.“We also believe that Oor Wullie’s Big Bucket Trail will make the entire population of Scotland smile, and on the back of a smile, amazing things can happen.” vw, px"  DC Thomson Media executive director Ellis Watson added: “Oor Wullie’s Big Bucket Trail is an amazing opportunity to bring Scotland together, to have fun, get active and enjoy some incredible art. And when people in Scotland come together, we all know how powerful that can be.”

title: delight for lego fans aberdeens pj live announces bricklive event
story: A wonderland for LEGO fans is to attract thousands of families from across the north-east to PJ Live for a great day out.The venue today announced it will bring the hugely popular BRICKLIVE show to Aberdeen for the first time, offering a vast array of events, displays and hands-on fun for three days in September.The LEGO-filled exhibition is described as the ultimate event for fans of the brick and will be the first consumer exhibition staged at PJ Live.Claire-Lena Miller-Davis, exhibitions manager at PJ Live, said: “We’re thrilled to be bringing BRICKLIVE to Aberdeen, especially to our brand-new venue.“This will be the first consumer exhibition held at PJ Live, offering a fantastic opportunity for families to come and see the new venue for the first time.”BRICKLIVE, is to be staged from Friday September  to Sunday September , and will let visitors, young and old, indulge their passion for LEGO on a grand scale.They can build their own car and race it down ramps, recreate iconic landmarks from around the world, visit the Ninjago Zone or recreate a Minecraft universe.The centrepiece of the touring exhibition is BRICKLIVE OCEAN.Created by the show’s master builders, it is a collection of brick-built sea creatures, from sharks to tuna, and octopuses to a giant killer whale.Organisers say it has the wow factor, with great photo opportunities as well as a chance to learn about the oceans and the creatures who live there.Wherever it is staged, it attracts thousands of families and master builders from around the world.Claire-Lena said: “With , square metres of brand-new, flexible event space at PJ Live, we’ve already been able to announce some other great consumer exhibitions and events and we’re delighted we can bring BRICKLIVE to the city for the first time.”Tickets for BRICKLIVE will go on sale at am on Friday.

title: winning kellys cat design unveiled by aberdeens lord provost
story: The winner of an Aberdeen school design competition has been unveiled.A total of  schools across Aberdeen took part in the local authority’s Kelly’s Cats competition, which saw pupils create their own versions with a Hollywood twist.Kelly’s Cats, designed by William Kelly, are a historic icon of the city, and were made for Union Bridge.Lord Provost Barney Crockett judged the competition, and announced Gilcomstoun School’s entry as the winner.It was designed by Primary  pupil Isla Tait, and was influenced by the Cheshire from Alice in Wonderland.Isla chose the character “because of how colourful and unique he is”.She worked alongside some of her peers in order to bring her design to le.Mr Crockett said he thought the designs had all been stunning, but he was particularly drawn to the Cheshire Cat.He added: “First of all, it’s very beautul.“I think the craft is very good, and it’s a bit weird, which is fun.”He praised the schools for taking part in the initiative, and encouraged members of the public to visit the council building to see the designs that are on public display.

title: letters to the editor week 18 2
story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSir,I read with interest the article in the April  edition of the Argyllshire Advertiser about the council’s autism strategy.I find it strange Councillor Green said the #strategy has reached a draft stage# when an Autism Strategy for Argyll and Bute already exists.It was commissioned by the council, produced in May  and signed off by council members. An implementation plan was produced in December  to cover the years -. Who in Argyll and Bute is responsible for this plan  How many of the outcomes have been achieved As someone who has been involved with autism personally and professionally for many years, I find it extremely disappointing there seems to be an inability by those in authority to get organised enough to address the issues and provide services for autistic people and their families.There is no need for further drafts and consultations.Someone in the authority needs to take responsibility for the existing strategy and implementation plan and get on with it.Maureen Mackintosh, Ardrishaig.Sir,Scotland’s small building firms had a strong start to , in contrast to the UK construction small and medium sized enterprisesector, according to the Federation of Master BuildersScotland.The FMB State of Trade Survey for the first quarter of , the only quarterly assessment of the UK-wide SME construction sector, showed SME workloads declined for the first time in six years.In Scotland, however, there was a jump of  per cent compared with the previous quarter. Thirty per cent of weighted responses were positive, up from  per cent from the fourth quarter of .It is encouraging the Scottish construction industry is bucking the wider Brexit trend with workloads and enquires in rude health. The UK-wide picture is very dferent, with the construction SME sector overall contracting for the first time in six years.Scotland’s good fortune could be due to fewer EU workers being based north of the border compared with other parts of the country, like in London where one in three construction workers are from the EU.Relying less heavily on migrant workers has meant the Scottish construction industry hasn’t fallen foul of thousands of EU workers ing home during the long march to Brexit due to no longer feeling welcome in the UK or sure of their future here.Scotland’s builders, however, must not be complacent. Looking ahead, the First Minister has indicated thatthe UK does leave the EU later this year, she wants a second independence referendum before the next Scottish Parliament election in . This additional political uncertainty, on top of the continued uncertainty stemming from Brexit, could impact on the construction sector in Scotland.The fear is a looming second referendum could test consumer confidence this year and next. For construction SMEs, this is particularly concerning as their prospects are vulnerable to dips in consumer confidence as so much work comes from the private domestic sector.Gordon Nelson, Director of FMB Scotland.Sir,I was joined by my fellow Conservative councillors in Kilmory recently as we discussed atthe numerous challenges facing Argyll and Bute.Ferry sailings, roads, education and the SNP#s late single farm payments were all mentioned.With the SNP hammering local authority spending and cutting our budgets, challenges in delivering services will become more prevalent.Despite this climate of cuts from the separatists, Conservative councillors are delivering for Argyll. This includes extra funding for the Tarbert and Lochgilphead Regeneration Fund, more funding for infrastructure and an increase in roads winter maintenance resources across Argyll.As ever, my fellow Conservatives and I will continue to fight non stop to make sure our rural constituency is not sidelined by this unceasingly urban and separatism-obsessed over centralising Scottish Government.Councillor Alastair Redman, Kintyre and Islands ward.Sir,I photographed this unusual visitor to Kilduskland Road, Ardrishaig, on April . Magpies are not a regular feature in Mid Argyll. We have not seen one in more than  years here.I think I saw a second one, either in pursuit or being pursued.Ron MacInnes, Ardrishaig.PIC:The Ardrishaig magpie, spotted in April. no_aMagpie

title: fynefest celebrates turning 10 with a beer
story: Laura MaxwellUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSubscribe NowFyneFest s for , celebrating hitting double figures with as much flair as ever.Beer, food and music: what more could anyone ask for  And there#s going to be plenty of each at this unique event, held over four days from Friday May .As usual, the field will be filled with trucks serving everything from pizza to curry and cupcakes. The most important part is the surprises amongst the favourites. No one knows what shawararama is but everyone wants to try it.The weekend will be headlined by FyneFest veterans Massaoke and Bombskare.Karaoke for the masses would get anyone dancing and singing, butMassaoke doesn#t do it, Bombskare#s bouncing hybrid of Scottish reggae will.MOJO favourites The Brambelles and Liam Somerville will be bringing their own flavour of soulful acoustic music to the field and Lochgilphead-based Bar None Community Choir will bring a twist to modern classics. Glasgow-based Samba Ya Bamba is a -piece brass band that will be heard before being seen.But that is the tip of the iceberg. Musicians from all over will offer everything from folk to rock to ceilidh and blues.As for the beer, this event proves to be the connoisseur of the pint-size world. More than  beers from  breweries are served at the main bar, with others in the Courtyard. There is also a cocktail teepee and cider is available. Water is available by the showers.There#s also the Timed Tappings at the main bar where you can get a taste of a limited brew that changes throughout the day.All these beers are colour-coded and listed in a grid found on the FyneFest website and detailed in your programme so you can even pre-plan what you want to drink.Should none of that take your fancy, there#s lots more to do around the festival, including tours of the nearby breweries, the FyneFest parade led by Samba Ya Bamba, the FyneFest quiz, morning yoga, a tent offering face, body and beard painting to get rightfully glam for the weekend and even the Champions League Final playing in the Courtyard.

story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : amLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSir,Councillors# and council officers# opposition to the Airigh Wind Farm proposal is disappointing.It is tenuous to say that a #jumbled# appearance of the turbines from the seaward south west approaches is a valid point for rejection.The preservation of panoramic quality does not provide for the social economic benefit to the rural community.Managing and improving the community-owned assets with today#s dearth of public funds and grants is challenging.Ardrishaig Community Trust is funding the renovation of our public hall solely with funds saved from a modest investment in the Allt Dearg Wind Farm.Should the proposed scheme have gone ahead there would have been an opportunity to invest in the enterprise, thus providing a signicant value revenue stream. That revenue would have contributed towards the management and improvement of assets and development of services within the Ardrishaig area for years ahead and for the benefit of current and future generations.Edward Laughton, director, Ardrishaig Community TrustSir,We often hear Argyll and Bute Council being slated.But this time they deserve all the praise they can get for cleaning and re-pointing Lochgilphead War Memorial. All it took was a request and the work was done in time for the Lochgilphead Armed Forces Day on June .Geordie Rhodick, chairman, LAFDSirFor the past two years, since he was elected to Argyll and Bute Council by the skin of his teeth, Councillor Alastair Redman has bombarded local newspapers with a constant stream of drivel attacking the Scottish Government.In his latest diatribe, he alleges that #the SNP has completely misjudged the mood of voters up and down the country#.I know it will be extremely painful for him, buthe can bring himself to review last week’s European Election results in Scotland, he’ll see the complete fallacy of this statement, andhe wants to look even closer to home, he’ll see that the SNP polled , votes in Argyll and Bute – , votes ahead of the Tories who came a distant fourth.Hardly a sign of his mythical assertion that Ruth Davidson is poised to be the next First Minister of Scotland.Robert Macintyre, Serpentine Road, RothesayDear PaulI write on behalf of constituents in Tarbert regarding the application for the Inveraray to Crossaig kV overhead line, which is with the [Scottish Government] Energy Consents Unit.A very large number of constituents have contacted me regarding this matter and almost  have signed a petition.They believe the proposal will have a major deleterious effect on the village and will be a huge and ugly blot on the landscape which, given the very attractive and scenic nature of the area, will be a big disincentive to tourism and will spoil the enjoyment of the area for residents as well.I have met with SSE to discuss this issue and have made it clear to them that the community wishes the company to come forward with alternative proposals, which must include undergrounding the cableno route can be found which does not spoil the visual amenity of the village.I know that the new line is needed for entirely understandable and positive reasons, and I have had only a few complaints from other parts of the area which will be affected.The opposition in Tarbert is virtually unanimous and there is also concern being expressed from those who know and value the area but do not live there.I hope that any consideration of consent will ensure that this issue is dealt with in accordance with the views of local people and I would be grateful to hear from you what the timescale is for that decision .Michael RussellSir,Newly-elected UK MEPs will take their seats in the European Parliament in July and it is crucial they recognise their signicant role in shaping the policies that impact on farming businesses. This new parliament will be pivotal in determining the nature of our future regulatory environment and we are keen and ready to meet with them.Our industry faces a number of challenges over the coming years, not just in relation to Brexit but on issues such as climate change, environmental policy, plant protection and animal health and welfare. There will also be opportunities for farming and we must ensure that we make the most of these opportunities to build a forward-looking, progressive and resilient sector that benefits farmers and consumers throughout the UK.We would like to invite all UK MEPs on to farms in their local areas to discuss a range of priority issues and to answer any questions that they might have. We are also inviting them to meet with us in person in Brussels and with our permanent staff in our Brussels office, the British Agriculture Bureau.Andrew McCornickMinette BattersJohn Daviesand Ivor Ferguson
